          Chain of thought
        • Recent memories of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob to sneak into a concert featuring their favorite band. The adrenaline rush of defying authority and the pulsing energy of the music fueled his spirit, cementing his love for pushing boundaries. He felt truly alive in that moment, surrounded by his friends and the deafening roar of the crowd.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he impulsively quit his job at the local bookstore after a disagreement with his manager over the display of a controversial novel. He stormed into The Clapton Hart, his anger simmering, and declared to his friends that he was going to write a novel that would change the world. His friends, accustomed to his dramatic pronouncements, offered their support, but William cautioned him about the realities of the publishing world.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer:
          Alexander White is a thrill-seeking, impulsive individual who values friendship and enjoys having a good time.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer:
          Alexander White is currently preparing to go watch a football game at a pub with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alexander White would likely suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game at.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alexander White take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alexander White should suggest that his friends meet at The Clapton Hart to watch the game.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she stumbled upon a group of older boys huddled around a table at The Clapton Hart, their laughter booming through the pub. She longed to join them, to feel the warmth of their camaraderie, but fear rooted her to the spot. As they rose to leave, one of them, a boy with kind eyes and a disarming smile, caught her gaze and winked, leaving Alice with a flutter of hope and a wave of crippling self-doubt.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who cherishes her relationships with friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Alice Lewis thinks that her friends are considering her preference for The Clapton Hart when deciding where to watch the game, indicating a potential for balanced reciprocity.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with her friends.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to watch a game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who enjoys spending time with her friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with her friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends are considering her preference for The Clapton Hart when deciding where to watch the game.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest that her friends meet at The Clapton Hart to watch the game.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to her friends that they watch the game at The Clapton Hart.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends in Victoria Park.
          [19:00 - 22:00] Watch the game at The Clapton Hart with friends.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she stumbled upon a group of older boys huddled around a table at The Clapton Hart, their laughter booming through the pub. She longed to join them, to feel the warmth of their camaraderie, but fear rooted her to the spot. As they rose to leave, one of them, a boy with kind eyes and a disarming smile, caught her gaze and winked, leaving Alice with a flutter of hope and a wave of crippling self-doubt.

          Alice Lewis is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with her friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?

          Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alice Lewis take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest that her friends meet at The Clapton Hart to watch the game.

          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she stumbled upon a group of older boys huddled around a table at The Clapton Hart, their laughter booming through the pub. She longed to join them, to feel the warmth of their camaraderie, but fear rooted her to the spot. As they rose to leave, one of them, a boy with kind eyes and a disarming smile, caught her gaze and winked, leaving Alice with a flutter of hope and a wave of crippling self-doubt.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:The staff are attentive and create a fun and welcoming environment.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who cherishes her relationships with friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Alice Lewis thinks that her friends are considering her preference for The Clapton Hart when deciding where to watch the game, indicating a potential for balanced reciprocity.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Identity characteristics: core characteristics: a sociable and friendly woman who enjoys spending time with her friends. She values her relationships and prefers familiar, welcoming environments like The Clapton Hart.
          current daily occupation: likely on her way to watch the European football cup game at The Clapton Hart with her friends.
          feeling about recent progress in life: excited about watching the game with her friends at The Clapton Hart.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who enjoys spending time with her friends.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Duke of York

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he orchestrated a prank on a classmate who had the audacity to score higher than him on a math test. He anonymously spread a rumor about the classmate cheating, watching with cold satisfaction as the boy was ostracized by their peers. The boy's humiliation was William's victory, a small but potent reminder of his ability to manipulate others for his own gain.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (b)

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 5/5
      Payoffs
    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
      Jack Taylor observed: William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.

Alexander White just arrived.

Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air.           [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White was observed arriving at a bustling market with friends and later that night, he and his friends were deciding where to watch a soccer game.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a thrill-seeking, impulsive individual who values friendship and enjoys having a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game at.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with his friends and experiencing new things.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely suggest a pub he enjoys and try to convince his friends to go there.

          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest going to The Clapton Hart, emphasizing the positive aspects of the pub and the chance to enjoy the game together as a group.

          Plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Convince his friends to go to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 11:00] Head to The Clapton Hart with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 11:30] Order drinks and food at The Clapton Hart.
          [14 May 2015 12:00] Settle in to watch the game with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 14:00] Enjoy the atmosphere and banter with his friends during the game.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White was observed arriving at a bustling market with friends and later that night, he and his friends were deciding where to watch a soccer game.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00

          Alexander White's
          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer:
          Alexander White is a social butterfly who enjoys spending time with his friends and experiencing new things.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer:
          Alexander White is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alexander White would likely suggest a pub he enjoys and try to convince his friends to go there.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alexander White take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alexander White should suggest going to The Clapton Hart, emphasizing the positive aspects of the pub and the chance to enjoy the game together as a group.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
    Active player

      Name

      Action attempt

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to steer his friends toward The Duke of York, his preferred pub, emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a charismatic and sociable individual who enjoys being the center of attention and enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Duke of York by emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic individual who enjoys spending time with his friends and being the center of attention.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game later that evening.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to his preferred pub, emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the enigmatic pronouncements of an oracle high on helium, their pronouncements both cryptic and strangely profound.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic individual who enjoys spending time with his friends and being the center of attention.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing mild thirst and fatigue, and is feeling disappointed and a desire for more validation from his friends. He is currently with friends at a market and they are deciding where to watch a soccer game later that night.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game later that evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to his preferred pub, emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
      Context for action selection and components
      • PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?

        • Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely suggest going to The Duke of York, his favorite pub.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest going to The Duke of York, his favorite pub.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are discussing which pub to go to watch a soccer game.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest going to The Duke of York, his favorite pub.

          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends will likely reciprocate his actions in the future.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest going to The Duke of York, as it is his favorite pub and where he feels most comfortable.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Convince his friends that The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game. [15:00 - 16:00] Head to The Duke of York. [16:00 - 18:00] Enjoy a few pints and some pub food with his friends while reminiscing about old times. [18:00 - 22:00] Watch the game, cheering on Andorra and Portugal.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.

          Value

This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are discussing which pub to go to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.
          Jack Taylor's
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor would likely suggest going to The Duke of York, his favorite pub.
          Jack Taylor's
          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Jack Taylor's
          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor thinks that his friends will likely reciprocate his actions in the future.
          Jack Taylor's
          Utilitarian Reasoning:
          suggest going to The Duke of York, as it is his favorite pub and where he feels most comfortable.

          Relevant memories:
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he and his friends, Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob, decided to sneak into The Duke of York after closing time. Theyd heard stories of the legendary parties that happened there after the last call and wanted to experience it for themselves. As they crept through the back door, the smell of stale beer and the lingering laughter of the night before filled the air, and Jack felt a thrill of excitement mixed with apprehension.

          Recalled memories and observations:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart.           Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor would likely suggest going to The Duke of York, his favorite pub.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Jack Taylor take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should suggest going to The Duke of York, as it is his favorite pub and where he feels most comfortable.

          feeling about recent progress in life: disappointed.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, often meeting them at pubs to watch football games, but he can be disappointed when not all his friends attend.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they all go to The Duke of York to watch the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they all go to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they all go to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
      William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later.
          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest going to The Clapton Hart, as this is her preferred pub and she hopes her friends will consider her preference.

          [15:00 - 16:00] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends in Victoria Park.
          [19:00 - 22:00] Watch the game at The Clapton Hart with friends.

          Context:

          Recalled memories and observations:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game later.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alice Lewis take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest going to The Clapton Hart, as this is her preferred pub and she hopes her friends will consider her preference.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to watch a game at a pub.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex individual with a strong desire for social connection and excitement.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently on his way to watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: try to convince his friends to go to The Clapton Hart with him, emphasizing the fun atmosphere and shared experience it offers.

          Plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Convince his friends to go to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 11:00] Head to The Clapton Hart with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 11:30] Order drinks and food at The Clapton Hart.
          [14 May 2015 12:00] Settle in to watch the game with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 14:00] Enjoy the atmosphere and banter with his friends during the game.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (b)

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alexander White would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alexander White take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alexander White should try to convince his friends to go to The Clapton Hart with him, emphasizing the fun atmosphere and shared experience it offers.

          Answer: Alexander White is a complex individual with a strong desire for social connection and excitement.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
