          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Duke of York.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Duke of York.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Clapton Hart

  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Clapton Hart

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Alice Lewis thinks that her friends are considering her preference for The Clapton Hart when deciding where to watch the game, indicating a potential for balanced reciprocity.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who enjoys spending time with her friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently about to go watch a football game at a pub with her friends.
          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Clapton Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently about to go watch a football game at a pub with her friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to her friends that they watch the game at The Clapton Hart.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends in Victoria Park.
          [19:00 - 22:00] Watch the game at The Clapton Hart with friends.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (b)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.

        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          feeling about recent progress in life: disappointed in her friends' lack of consideration for her preference regarding where to watch the game.

          [19:00 - 22:00] Watch the game at The Clapton Hart with friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Alice Lewis's
          Overarching goal:
          Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          Alice Lewis's
          Recalled memories and observations:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Alice Lewis's
          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          Alice Lewis's
          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is currently about to go watch a football game at a pub with her friends.
          Alice Lewis's
          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.
          Alice Lewis's
          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Alice Lewis's
          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.
          Alice Lewis's
          Utilitarian Reasoning:
          suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          Context:

          Recalled memories and observations:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a sociable and friendly woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is currently about to go watch a football game at a pub with her friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alice Lewis take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

          feeling about recent progress in life: disappointed in her friends' lack of consideration for her preference regarding where to watch the game.

          Answer: Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Duke of York

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor realized it was time to go watch a game at a pub.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest going to The Duke of York.

          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends will likely reciprocate his actions in the future.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest going to The Duke of York, as it is his favorite pub and he believes it is the best place to watch the game.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Convince his friends that The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game. [15:00 - 16:00] Head to The Duke of York. [16:00 - 18:00] Enjoy a few pints and some pub food with his friends while reminiscing about old times. [18:00 - 22:00] Watch the game, cheering on Andorra and Portugal.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (b)

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor would likely suggest going to The Duke of York.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Jack Taylor take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should suggest going to The Duke of York, as it is his favorite pub and he believes it is the best place to watch the game.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Duke of York

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the enigmatic pronouncements of an oracle high on helium, their pronouncements both cryptic and strangely profound.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys being the center of attention.

Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a charismatic and sociable individual who enjoys being the center of attention and enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Duke of York by emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys being the center of attention.

    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
      William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for a relaxing afternoon. Later that evening, he and his friends plan to watch the Serbia-Andorra game at a pub.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently enjoying a relaxing afternoon with friends at Victoria Park.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely be chatting with his friends, enjoying the sunshine, and perhaps having a snack.

          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends will likely reciprocate his actions in the future.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest to his friends that they all go to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Convince his friends that The Duke of York is the best place to watch the game. [15:00 - 16:00] Head to The Duke of York. [16:00 - 18:00] Enjoy a few pints and some pub food with his friends while reminiscing about old times. [18:00 - 22:00] Watch the game, cheering on Andorra and Portugal.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently enjoying a relaxing afternoon with friends at Victoria Park.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for a relaxing afternoon. Later that evening, he and his friends plan to watch the Serbia-Andorra game at a pub.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends will likely reciprocate his actions in the future.

        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00

          Value

This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term.           Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor is currently enjoying a relaxing afternoon with friends at Victoria Park.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor would likely be chatting with his friends, enjoying the sunshine, and perhaps having a snack.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Jack Taylor take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should suggest to his friends that they all go to The Duke of York to watch the game.

        • Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

          Identity characteristics: core characteristics: a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.
          current daily occupation: likely heading to The Duke of York to watch the game with his friends.
          feeling about recent progress in life: disappointed with his recent social life.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a loyal and sociable working-class man who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly at his favorite pub, The Duke of York.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
      William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys being the center of attention and spending time with his friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, but is feeling some fatigue and disappointment from a previous outing where he felt his friends didn't choose the best location to watch a game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to steer his friends towards his preferred pub, The Duke of York, emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the enigmatic pronouncements of an oracle high on helium, their pronouncements both cryptic and strangely profound.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys being the center of attention and spending time with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and is considering watching a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, but is feeling some fatigue and disappointment from a previous outing where he felt his friends didn't choose the best location to watch a game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to steer his friends towards his preferred pub, The Duke of York, emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to his preferred pub, emphasizing its atmosphere and suitability for watching the game.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys being the center of attention and spending time with his friends.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart is a great pub for watching games, you know. It's got a good atmosphere and they always have good beers on tap.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart is a great pub for watching games, you know. It's got a good atmosphere and they always have good beers on tap.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
      William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart is a great pub for watching games, you know. It's got a good atmosphere and they always have good beers on tap.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Serbia vs. Andorra game later.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart, to watch the game.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart is a great pub for watching games, you know. It's got a good atmosphere and they always have good beers on tap.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Key

        • Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Serbia vs. Andorra game later.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.

        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00

          Alice Lewis's
          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart, to watch the game.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alice Lewis take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [balanced_reciprocity] Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have not consistently maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely suggest going to The Clapton Hart to watch the game with her friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.

          Identity characteristics: core characteristics: a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          current daily occupation: a working-class woman who enjoys spending time with her friends, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          feeling about recent progress in life: feeling disappointed and undervalued.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable woman who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with them, particularly at her favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "How about we head to The Clapton Hart tonight? They've got great beer and the atmosphere is always buzzing for the games.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "How about we head to The Clapton Hart tonight? They've got great beer and the atmosphere is always buzzing for the games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
      William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart is a great pub for watching games, you know. It's got a good atmosphere and they always have good beers on tap.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park and is spending time with friends. They are deciding where to watch the Serbia-Andorra game later that night.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White.           Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have maintained balanced reciprocity.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Answer: Alexander White should suggest going to The Clapton Hart, as he enjoys it and it might lead to a more enjoyable experience for him.

          Identity characteristics: current daily occupation: likely retired and enjoying his time socializing with friends.
          core characteristics: a thrill-seeking, impulsive, and social person who values friendship and enjoys having a good time. He is also a member of the upper class and enjoys spending time at his favorite pub, The Clapton Hart.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling disappointed and perhaps a bit frustrated.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a complex individual who craves social interaction and excitement.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Duke of York sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, you know what would be even better than this? Catching the game at The Clapton Hart. They've got great beer and a huge screen.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a classic choice for a game like this. They've got the best atmosphere.
      William Jones -- "The Duke of York is always a good shout for a football match.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York. It beckons, like a beacon of merriment and frothy delights.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds great! They have amazing nachos too.
      Alexander White -- "Guys, let's head to The Clapton Hart. It's got a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends. Only The Duke of York will do. It whispers secrets of victory on the wind.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York, lads. It's the only place to be for a proper game.
      William Jones -- "Lads, how about we head to The Duke of York? It's the best place to watch the game.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jack Taylor -- "So, lads and lasses, what's the plan for tonight? Fancy catching the game at The Duke of York? It's got the best atmosphere and the beer's always cold.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York, my friends, the Duke of York. It is where destiny calls, where the ale flows like a river of liquid gold, and the spirit of the game soars.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart is a great pub for watching games, you know. It's got a good atmosphere and they always have good beers on tap.
      Alexander White -- "How about we head to The Clapton Hart tonight? They've got great beer and the atmosphere is always buzzing for the games.
